posts.cooked:
Our team recently participated in the North Star Regional with our robot, the Kitbot, equipped with tank drive and the ability to perform a shallow climb. Despite the robot’s strong capabilities and minor issues resolved through fixes, we unfortunately didn’t secure an alliance placement. However, the experience was rewarding, teaching us valuable lessons.

Compared to previous years, our robot struggled with basic movement and defense, making tank drive an upgrade for us moving forward. To explore new possibilities, we considered switching to a different drive train, specifically Mecanum wheels proposed by our coach. He suggested starting with Mecanum due to its enhanced maneuverability on the field, despite concerns about reduced efficiency when navigating towards stations.

Switching to Mecanum would offer improved field navigation but may complicate station alignment and return paths. Our team is passionate about exploring Swerve as our long-term goal, but transitioning from tank to Mecanum presents a middle ground between stability and adaptability. While we’re open to experimenting, we’re cautiously evaluating whether Mecanum will provide sufficient benefits given our limited off-season preparation time.

Ultimately, our interest lies in balancing immediate needs with long-term vision. If the transition to Mecanum proves successful, we can then consider upgrading to Swerve. For now, we’re gathering feedback to decide the best path forward for our team’s growth and competitive edge.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Importantly, I want to compare Mecanum and Swerve drivetrains. One is not a step toward the other; they are fundamentally different systems with distinct requirements. While Mecanum may seem simpler to set up due to additional gearboxes, Swerve becomes increasingly viable with the right components. Both require unique mechanical setups and programming logic. From a practical standpoint, Mecanum shouldn't mimic Swerve behavior because it could perform worse compared to Swerve-driven robots. My advice is to avoid Mecanum altogether and instead focus on maximizing Swerve capabilities, as it currently dominates in terms of performance and adoption rates.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
We spent from our Rookie year (2015) to last season as a Tank. Towards the end, we moved from CIMs to NEOs for our drive motors, which was a significant change. We changed the white wheels to black for better traction.

At the end of the school year last year, we switched to swerve. Over the past few years, we pieced together the swerve system, purchasing parts whenever we could afford them. This year, we ran swerve for the first time.

There is a knowledge gap we needed to overcome, and we are still learning.

Bottom line: If you want a Corvette, never settle for Chevette. There are numerous swerve options available, and while coding can be challenging, there is plenty of support available if you encounter problems.

I would encourage anyone considering a switch to join us in exploring the swerve system—they will never look back once they try it!
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked: I saw a topic and thought someone had posted about a 2019 open topic. Mecanum can be an engaging academic exercise when exploring drivetrain history but isn’t suitable for competition today. Prepare for an off-season swerve drive. While the basics are straightforward, tuning, driver practice, accurate path following, and maintenance are crucial, especially during the season. We’ve been doing swerve for four years and continue to discover new things. Mecanum won’t help us achieve our goals in that regard.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
mecanum is a dead end
If it is at all affordable I would look to the example of teams like 9092 and 9543 They built kit bots in their rookie year and then in year 2 essentially built kit bot or kit bot like with a swerve drivebase and saw their performance increase substantially

Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can reach peak efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will do well. Additionally, consider improving software to enhance your driver. Each of your Venoms has internal encoders, so use them to boost autos or create driver aids. This concept is worth expanding on. A Mecanum drive that isn't driven like a Swerve should ideally be a Tank drive, and Mecanum wheels can lose efficiency when moving non-perpendicularly relative to their axis. Teams sometimes opt to drive it like a Tank due to this inefficiency or issues with drivetrain gearing, which can cause overheating during strafing. Speed and acceleration decrease in such movements, and odometry isn't possible, requiring dead wheels. Mecanum wheels are highly sensitive to uneven mass distribution.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Rookie year (2015)... Towards the end… we moved from CIMs to NEOs for motors.

Your point stands: a simple motor upgrade has an impact from basic CIMs. But wait, there's something wrong here—rev was founded around 2014/2015 and NEO was just a thought in Greg and others' minds that same year. Regardless, in 2015-2017, we had some wild and innovative drivetrains discussed on that site.
Please don’t do mechanum. What someone mentioned earlier about "do not pick" lists is true.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: We switched to NEOs in 22 for our drivetrain. When you are a small, underfunded team—you do what you can.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Lauchlin
posts.cooked: My opinion is this for current day FIRST Robotics Competition: If a team can do swerve, do swerve. If they cannot, do the kitbot chassis. Any other option beyond those two is a less effective strategy for a team and their season.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked: I watched your North Star matches. I’ve been involved in the design of numerous FRC robots since the 1960s, have helped to start several FRC teams since 1996, and have over 40 years of motor engineering background. Your team performed well with the basic L1 design this year. Adding more pushing power would have given a small advantage, while mecanum drive would have been a significant disadvantage. FTC is a great program, and mecanum drive performs well there. However, in Michigan, FTC is limited to middle school teams, and many of our best FRC students progress to important roles after starting in FTC. None of those students would recommend mecanum for an FRC robot.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: The text discusses comparisons between different types of robots used in FIRST Robotics competitions, particularly focusing on Mecanum and Swerve robots. It acknowledges that Mecanum is comprehensive but advises against its use now, citing inefficiencies and difficulties in achieving straight movement without extra coding. Mentors who spent two years mentoring a team using Mecanum encountered persistent challenges despite their efforts, highlighting the importance of aligning the center of gravity for successful navigation. In contrast, Swerve robots offer improvements, providing better performance and ease without the drawbacks associated with Mecanum. The text also notes that in certain specific games, such as 2015, Mecanum might have had potential advantages, but these were negated by issues related to tote weights affecting the robot's balance.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Concurring opinion.  
It is possible to have an extremely effective and inspiring Mecanum robot. The team 6167 used a Mecanum Everybot to captain roles at their last two FSC events, though there are important considerations:

- They were able to stay out of the way while running processor algae, adding significant value.
- Their ability to climb during competitions was particularly valuable, as many top teams avoided climbs altogether.
- This year’s competition became more Mecanum-friendly due to shorter sprints and reduced power loss compared to other robots like Crescendo or Charged Up.
- This wouldn’t be their first time competing with Mecanum technology.

Our top two robots in the EPA league are ranked #138 and #253, alongside #598, #728, and #1766 in Houston.  

While I criticize the swerve tax and its impact on team rosters, Mecanum technology appears to be regressing in 2025. Without drastic rule changes for 2026, there are two viable solutions:

1. Use the AM14U6 chassis with HiGrip wheels, your preferred Toughbox Mini ratio, and a drivetrain motor. Consider adding an 8WD upgrade kit if you anticipate wheel usage.
2. Opt for COTS swerve solutions.

The latter offers a higher competitive edge when implemented properly. If resources limit your ability to adopt swerve, the former remains a reasonable alternative.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Spend all the time you'd invest making mecanum work into fundraising the money you need for a swerve drive. With YAGSL and other code solutions for swerve, the barrier to entry for a good swerve chassis is really just the money.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Introduction  
The purpose of this report is to analyze the performance of our team's robotic system. We conducted several tests to evaluate the system's efficiency and reliability under different conditions. The results indicate that the system performed exceptionally well in controlled environments but faced challenges in unstructured settings due to limited sensor accuracy.  

Methods  
We implemented a series of algorithms to enhance the system's processing capabilities. These include advanced pathfinding algorithms and machine learning models for data analysis. The integration of these components was done using a unified framework to ensure seamless communication between subsystems. Testing was conducted in a simulated environment before deployment in real-world scenarios.  

Results  
Our experiments revealed significant improvements in system performance metrics such as response time and error reduction. However, some unexpected issues arose during testing, particularly with the adaptive filtering mechanism, which introduced delays in critical data processing.  

Conclusion  
In summary, while our system shows great potential, there are areas where further optimization is needed. Specifically, enhancing the adaptive filtering mechanism and improving sensor accuracy are critical next steps for achieving consistent performance across various operational scenarios.

If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. Actually even more generally, mecanum drives rarely drive straight even if the CG is centered and your frame is built to good tolerances unless you solve a rather complicated controls problem. The easiest way to demonstrate it is to drive a mecanum drive bot forwards, then suddenly sideways. Two of the wheels need to swap directions, but because the wheels and robot has inertia and non-zero latency, the robot skews and you aren’t straight anymore. This isn’t unsolvable, but it’s outside the means of almost every FRC team to solve, hence why most mecanum FRC and FTC bots don’t drive straight to some degree or another unless driven slowly.  

It is possible to solve this problem (I’ve personally done so), its really hard (you need to use a cartesian-space inverse dynamics controller, while extrapolating out latency and avoiding voltage, current, and traction saturations), while swerve is just less susceptible to these issues due to having more traction and throwing 400W brushless motors at the problem.

I would not recommend Mechanum if you’re looking to be a more competitive robot. While it’s used for FTC robots, Mechanum allows your robot to be more easily pushed around. There was only one robot at one of our comps this year that had Mechanum, and it was constantly being pushed around by defending robots, leading it to be put on our no-pick list.

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: Our team ran Mecanum wheels in 2021, a Covid year, and they were flashy but didn't provide much benefit compared to Swerve wheels. While Swerve offers excellent tools, it's expensive, and our team benefits from sponsors' grants focusing on Swerve bases. Seek grants from sponsors to support innovation and STEM projects.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can reach peak efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will do well. Drive practice is critically important and swerve gives you two big advantages towards this goal.

Building a swerve drive base is dead easy. Cut 4 2x1 tubes to the appropriate lengths, bolt on your modules and cut a quick and dirty belly pan out of 5mm plywood. Attach your electronics. Once you decide on a robot size, you should be up and practicing driving in a day or two.

Swerve gets you "field oriented" (as opposed to "robot oriented") controls. This makes driving so much easier. This was how we did our "first" swerve, which we called "Barbie Bot."

The first swerve I drove was in 2012; it was a ludicrous home-built vehicle.
